poem:
Open Doors

September unlocks its architectural secrets,  
a harvest moon illuminating shadows 
in forgotten bingo halls,  
where ghosts of numbers once drifted.  
Nuclear bunkers whisper history's safe secrets,  
Tom Cruise paths offer imaginary flights.  
Virgos and Libras balance calendars,  
as strangers wander palaces  
to touch the stories once hidden—  
keys turning in silent, patient locks.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Bingo halls, nuclear bunkers and the Tom Cruise trail: the best of this year’s Open House September: it’s the month of the harvest moon (usually); Vogue’s most celebrated issue; and the dominion of Virgos and Libras. But it’s also when the UK, and much of Europe, opens doors usually closed to the public, with various organisations offering rare and free access to architectural gems, cultural institutions, science hubs, courts, palaces, medieval castles, embassies – and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
